name: Before getting started : Person taking interview

questions.text: Who is doing this interview?

acceptedValues.testator: The person whose Will it is (i.e. the testator)
acceptedValues.solicitor: A solicitor or will-writer on behalf of a client
acceptedValues.other: The testator, with assistance from someone else (e.g. a friend or relative)

questions.text: Where do you live and have most of your property?
Sorry! Our service isn't suitable for users outside of the United Kingdom. You'll need to take legal advice from a professional lawyer in the country where you live.

questions.note:
This section is about how we protect the personal data you are about to enter and you giving us permission to use that data in limited ways.

What we may and may not do with your interview answers is set out in the Processor Terms. Click here to read our Processor Terms (opens in new tab).

Here's a summary of those Processor Terms:

1. We will use the information you enter to system-generate a draft Will.

2. The information is stored securely on Amazon Web Services' servers in the UK.

3. Once you have completed the interview, we may recommend or request you book a free video appointment to discuss your needs with our legal team or with a firm of solicitors or professional will writers. When you choose to book with a firm other than Bequeathed, we will transfer your information to that firm.

4. In order that we may provide you with support and, subject to you signing a Client Care Letter, with legal advice and your Will, some information will be transferred to our user supporter system, Intercom. Intercom processes information in the US at Amazon Web Services.

5. Apart from the transfers at 3 and 4 above, we will not transfer your information to any third party unless you explicitly request us to do so.

6. We will keep the information for as long as we operate Bequeathed (so you can come back and make a new Will without having to enter all the information again) and afterwards for Keeping Records and Accounts under the Privacy Policy you accepted when you registered to use our service. Click here to read our Privacy Policy (opens in new tab).

7. You may at any time request that we erase the information and we will do so under the terms of our Privacy Policy.

If you wish to proceed please tick the box to consent

acceptedValues.confirmed: I consent to Bequeathed using my personal information as described

name: Before getting started : Permission to record

questions.note:
Our system will help you record four short videos of you answering some straightforward questions. Each recording will be a maximum of one minute long.

Your video responses ensure we fully understand your circumstances and wishes so we can give you the best possible advice. Your video responses also help us confirm:

  • you do have the understanding required to legally make a valid Will, and
  • all the decisions you are making are your own, and
  • you are not being influenced by someone else.

Those three aspects are crucial to us putting the necessary safeguards in place to reduce the chances of a successful legal challenge to your Will after your death.

It is ok for someone to assist you with this interview. But it is important you answer every question yourself, without prompting from anyone else. Please also ensure you keep your face visible at all times.

questions.text: Do you consent to having your video and audio recorded and stored securely subject to the data protection provisions of the Processor Terms and Privacy Policy you accepted earlier?

name: Before getting started : What you want your Will to achieve

questions.text: Now, please give a summary of your final wishes, for example; who do you want to leave any money and/or property that you own to? Also, do tell us if there is anyone you specifically want to exclude and why.

name: Before getting started : Your current situation

questions.text: Finally, for this section of the interview, please tell us briefly about your relationships.
questions.note:
For example, let us know if you are married, living with someone, single, divorced, or separated, and if you have any children or step-children, including any children from a previous relationship.

Also let us know if any previous relationships ended with divorce or the dissolution of a civil partnership. We'll ask for more detail later, so we only need a short summary in this video answer.

questions.text: Please indicate whether you will be able to read and sign your Will.

acceptedValues.None: Able to read and sign the Will

name: Before getting started : Visual impairment - more information

questions.note: It will be necessary for someone to read the completed will to you. What is the full name of that person? (You can change this at your legal appointment if you change your mind.)

name: You and your Will : Your circumstances and wishes

questions.text:
This interview records the information we need about your circumstances and your wishes to help you make your Will.

At the end of the interview, we will analyse your answers to present advice on any additional steps that you must take or should take to ensure your estate and beneficiaries are adequately protected. That advice will determine how we help you complete the process and make your Will.

  1. Please answer the questions on each page by typing your answer or recording a short video. Some questions are marked as Optional and all others are required, meaning you do need to answer them please.
  2. Once you are happy with your answers on a page, click "Save and continue".
  3. If you want to change an answer, you can either select the "Back to previous page" button or click on the section in the left hand menu that you wish to return to. You will also be able to read a Summary of your answers at the end of the interview and edit them if you wish.
  4. If you need to find information or have a think about your answer, click the "Save and exit" button. You can then log back in another time and select My Wishes to continue with the interview.

Your answers should be about you only. If your spouse or partner also wishes to make their Will then there is an option to tell us about that later so they too can provide their separate instructions.

If you need our support at any point, select one of the Help options or just open the chat function which is usually on the bottom right of your screen.

name: You and your Will : Personal information

questions.text: What is your full name?
questions.note: If you are helping someone with this interview, please enter the name of the person for whom the will is being made.

questions.text: First line of address?
Second line of address? (optional)
Third line of address? (optional)
Town or City?
County? (optional)
What is your postcode?
What is your date of birth?
What is your sex?

name: You and your Will : What a Will does

questions.note:
In a moment, we will ask you to record a video telling us what you want your Will to say. But first, it is part of our professional duty to reassure ourselves that you understand the purpose and effect of making a Will.

Please therefore record a short statement summarising what you think a Will is and what it does.

When you click ‘Start new recording’, your device may display a prompt asking you to allow our website to access your camera and microphone. Please allow. You will not give our system any access to the information on your computer, it simply enables our website to record the video and the audio for this interview only.

name: You and your Will : Testamentary capacity

questions.note:
It is important that every person who makes a Will fully understands what they are doing. This is known as Testamentary Capacity.

To help us consider that, please indicate if you:

  • have been diagnosed with an illness recognised as being capable of affecting testamentary capacity (e.g. cancer, dementia, epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease etc); or
  • have had drug or alcohol-related problems; or
  • have had a recent traumatic event (physical or emotional); or
  • have concerns, or concerns have been expressed by anyone else, as to your mental capacity (e.g. episodes of drowsiness, confusion, forgetfulness or a marked change in personality).

acceptedValues.yes: Yes - one or more of the above applies

Your Will needs to name a guardian who will take care of your children if, and only if, the other person with parental responsibility for a child has died before you. That guardian appointment in your Will needs to acknowledge who else has parental responsibility, even if you or your child are no longer in contact with the other parent.

name: Your estate : What you currently own

questions.text: Please record a short video to tell us about the main assets in your estate as they are now. We appreciate this may change during your lifetime, so for now you only need to think about the main items.
questions.note:
For example, whether you currently own a property, or if you have savings and investments.

Do also tell us about anything else you feel may be relevant. But we'll ask for more detail later, so only need a short summary in this video answer.

questions.text: Do you own your own residential property?
Do you own any property jointly with another person?
Do you own more than one property?
Do you own any foreign property?
Do you own any commercial property or have any business interests?

name: Your estate : Value of your estate

questions.text: Roughly, what is the current value of everything you own yourself, less everything you owe to others? If you own property or bank accounts jointly, include half the value in your estimate. Lump sum payments from pensions and life insurance are not normally included.

For most people, the decision about who will inherit is very straightforward: they want everything (known as the residuary estate) to go to one person (such as a spouse or partner) or to a group of people to be shared between them (such as children or siblings).

If that is the type of arrangement you also want, select Yes below. (You will be asked who that single person or group of people is later in the interview.)

However, some people want to make specific gifts of property or money or other items to specific people. Everything else (the residuary estate) then goes to one person or a group of people to be shared between them.

If you want to take that alternative route, then select ‘No’ below.
Do you want to leave everything you have as a single gift?

acceptedValues.Yes: Yes, I want everything to go to one person or one group of people
acceptedValues.No: No, I want to list specific gifts first

name: Gift of assets and personal possessions : More information

questions.text: Where would you like to set out which items should go to which people?
questions.note:
Making gifts of personal possessions in your will provides you with certainty that the gifts will go to the person or people that you want them to go to.

However, if you change your mind then you will need to make a new will.

To avoid that, you can leave those items to your executors/trustees instead and write a letter of wishes asking them to give certain possessions to certain people: it's not binding but most executors/trustees will do their best to follow wishes.

You can then change your letter of wishes at any time.

name: Gift of assets and personal possessions : Letter of wishes

questions.text: Who should receive the items and then be responsible for distributing them in accordance with the letter of wishes?
Do you wish the recipient to receive their personal possessions free of tax?

name: Gift of assets and personal possessions : Letter of wishes - Specific individual

questions.text: What is the full name of the person who should receive the items and then be responsible for distributing them in accordance with the letter of wishes?

name: Gift of assets and personal possessions : In the will

questions.text: Do you want the recipients to receive the items free of tax?
What is the item?
questions.note:
This could be personal possessions such as furniture, pets or pedigree animals, or the balance of a bank account or cash savings.

For specific monetary gifts or gifts of any interest in property, please use the 'Cash gifts' and 'Gift of land' sections of the interview.

Pedigree animals of high value will usually incur a liability for inheritance tax.

Please describe the item as clearly as you can using the word "my". For example: "my gold Rotary watch with the brown strap" or "my bank account with HSBC, sort code 11-22-33, account number 1234567".

questions.text: What is the full name of the person to receive the item?

name: Gift of assets and personal possessions

questions.text:
Personal items

You selected the option to leave specific items to specific people and then leave everything else to a person or group of people.

We will get to property and cash in a moment. Use this section to leave things like a car or an item of jewellery.

You can also use it to leave shares in a company or, for example, a bank or savings account. Make sure to describe each item as well as you can.
Are there any specific items, other than cash or property, you wish to leave to specific particular people?

name: Gift of land,buildings, etc : Decisions about property

questions.text: How do you want to leave property such as buildings and land?
questions.note:
Dealing with property can be complicated. But, don't worry: the legal firm will discuss it with you in your free 30 minute appointment.

Please read the following guidance before answering the next set of questions.

If you own your property with someone else as joint tenants (which many couples do) then you each already own 100% of the property: that's because the law considers you to each hold the entire property "on trust" for the other.

So, when you die, your partner already owns 100% and therefore there is no share for you to leave in your will.

If you own as joint tenants and want to leave your share to someone who is not the other owner of the property, you will need to sever the joint tenancy. You can discuss this with the legal firm in your free 30 minute appointment but the cost of severing the tenancy will be extra.

If you own your property on your own, or with someone else as tenants in common, then you can leave your share to someone without any further steps.

Choose the first option below if you want to leave a particular property or share of property to people who are not going to inherit everything else (for example you want to give a particular house to a brother, but everything else is to go to your sister). You will then be asked for the details.

Choose the second option in the question below, if you want your property to be inherited by the same person or group of people who will inherit everything else. If this is the case, you will not be asked any further questions about it.

Choose the third option if you do not own any property.

(If you own foreign property, you should tell the legal firm in your appointment as there may be specific rules in the country concerned that affect how the property is dealt with following your death.)

acceptedValues.Yes: I want to make a specific gift of a house, property or land to a named person or persons
acceptedValues.No: I want to leave all houses, properties or land to my residuary beneficiaries
acceptedValues.Will: I have no houses, property or land to leave separately in my Will

name: Gift of land,buildings, etc : Rights to the property

questions.text:
How do you want the property to pass?

You have two choices: outright or for lifetime only.

If you select ‘outright’, the recipient will own the property and can do what they want with it, including leaving it to whoever they want in their own will.

If you want to control what the recipient can do with the property after your death, including who inherits it when they die, then you need to give it to them only for their lifetime. That is known as a ‘life interest'.

The recipient of a life interest can receive the rental income from the property or live in it. Their entitlement will come to an end on their death (or, if you choose, on a subsequent marriage/civil partnership). The property then passes to whomever you state in your will.

The legal firm will discuss your reasons for creating a life interest with you in the free 30 minute appointment. Please note: it is likely the firm will need to provide you with additional advice in relation to your life interest beyond 30 minutes. If this is the case, then the firm will provide you with a quote for that advice.

If you want to leave more than one property then you will also need to discuss that with the legal firm as there may be tax implications. For the time being, just put the details of one property in this interview and ask the firm about the others. There will be an additional fee for dealing with multiple properties.
Would you like the recipient to receive the property outright or for their lifetime only?

acceptedValues.Select: The executors should pay the cash gift to other charities which they may select

acceptedValues.Select: The executors should pay the cash gift to other charities which they may select

questions.text:
You selected the option to leave a percentage of the value of everything you own (your “estate”) to charity. That is known as a charitable legacy. Thank you.

We will ask you which charities you wish to benefit from your legacy in a moment.
First, please tell us what percentage of your estate you would like to leave to charity?
How do you want the charitable legacy to be divided?

acceptedValues.In equal shares: I wish to leave my charitable legacy to one single charity or several charities in equal shares
acceptedValues.In unequal shares: I wish to leave my charitable legacy to several charities in unequal shares

name: Gifts to charities : Charitable legacy - Share

questions.text: What is the percentage of the estate you would like to leave? Please give your answer in whole numbers.

name: Gifts to charities : Charitable legacy - Survivorship

questions.text: Do you still want to give this legacy to charity if you die before your spouse?
questions.note: You should only choose "Yes" if you are sure your spouse or partner will have sufficient funds available to them after your death and are committed to making the charitable gift no matter what.
conditions: 'testator.marital_status' in ('Married', 'Partner in civil partnership', 'Divorced and remarried')

Please tick the box next to any of our partner charities you wish to benefit from your charitable legacy. Our system will then automatically include their details in your will.

You also have the option to select from our database of 23,000 UK charities.

You can choose to support as many charities as you like. But as you have already told our system that you wish to leave to charity, you must select at least one.

Select All | Select None

questions.text: Share of the charitable legacy?
questions.note: Of your total charitable legacy, what percentage should this charity get? The total for all the charities you want to include in this section should add up to 100%. e.g. If you said you want 10% of your estate to go to charity, and want two charities to share unequally in that, you might put 70% for the first charity and 30% for the second.

name: Gifts to charities : Charitable legacy - Share

questions.text: Share of the charitable legacy?
questions.note: Of your total charitable legacy, what percentage should this charity get? The total for all the charities you want to include in this section should add up to 100%. e.g. If you said you want 10% of your estate to go to charity, and want two charities to share unequally in that, you might put 70% for the first charity and 30% for the second.

questions.text: Do you have any beneficial interests in property that is currently held in trust?
questions.note:
A beneficial interest is the entitlement to benefit from property, without necessarily being the legal owner of it.

In a trust situation, the trustees are the legal owners, and anyone who will benefit from the trust has a beneficial interest.

questions.text: Have you made any gifts during your lifetime (other than to your spouse/civil partner or to charity) which you still receive a benefit from (e.g. where you live rent-free in a house that you have given to a member of your family)?
In the event that a charity to which you have left a legacy no longer exists at the date of your death, what should happen to the legacy?

acceptedValues.Similar: The executors should pay the cash gift to other charities with the same or similar objects as the charity no longer in existence
acceptedValues.Select: The executors should pay the cash gift to other charities which they may select

questions.text: In the event that a charity to which you have left a legacy has merged with another charity by the date of your death, what should happen to the legacy?

acceptedValues.New: The executors should pay the cash gift to the charity formed as a result of the merger
acceptedValues.Select: The executors should pay the cash gift to other charities which they may select

questions.text: If the reduced rate of inheritance tax of 36% will not apply to the charitable gift when you die, should the legacy lapse?
After ensuring they've looked after their loved ones, many of our users do choose to include a gift to a good cause they're passionate about. And that helps the UK's charities make a real difference.
You don't have to include a gift in your will to charity. Your Will For Good is free whatever you decide. But we hope it's something you'll consider.
Do you wish to leave any gifts to charity?

acceptedValues.yes: Yes, I'd like to use my Will For Good to support charity
acceptedValues.no: No, I would rather not include a gift to charity in my Will For Good

questions.text:
Please provide the details of any cash gifts you want to make here.

You can choose to make a gift index-linked. This means that the actual amount of the gift will increase in line with inflation, measured between the date of your will and the date of your death.

questions.text: Do you want the gift to be index-linked?
Do you wish the recipient to receive the gift free of tax?
questions.note:
Any tax due will be payable by your estate if you choose Yes. This may affect the amount that is left to distribute to the principal beneficiaries of your will.

If the value of your estate when you die is below the nil rate band (currently 325,000), there will be no tax to pay regardless of your answer to this question.

For more information, see our page How does inheritance tax work (opens in new tab)?

What is the postcode of the executor?
Choosing your executors
questions.note:
The executors will be responsible for administering your estate after death. They also become Trustees if your Will creates any trusts, including for children.

It is fine to ask family or friends to be executors. Many people do. But it is a crucial role and it can be difficult. Check with them first whether they are willing and able.

Alternatively, if you have a complicated estate or do not have family or friends you are able or willing to ask, you can appoint Professional Executors.

Their fees for administering your estate will be paid from your estate after your death. Those fees can be significant so are normally only worthwhile if you have a complex estate or if you have a high value estate.

Bear in mind also, that if you think family and friends who could be executors may need help, they can always seek professional advice at the time.

questions.text: May we let the charities included in your Will know your contact details and how you've chosen to support their work?
questions.note:
Thank you for supporting the work of great causes in your Will For Good. Your chosen charities appreciate you joining their community of valued supporters.

They would love to get in touch to say thank you, and to keep you updated on the difference your gift will make and other ways of getting involved. You can contact a charity at any time to change how they communicate with you.
